Award.AwardTitle: SHB: Small: Use of Gaming Peripherals in Acute Rehabilitation of Balance Following Stroke

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Balance disorders are a common problem following stroke, and the restoration of balance represents a key return to normalcy that can make the critical difference between returning home and remaining in long-term care. Current balance rehabilitation practice in the acute phase of recovery, however, is often driven by subjective feedback and experience, rather than by objective observation/analysis because of cost and time constraints. This study plans to investigate how gaming peripherals can be used as an inexpensive means to enhance balance rehabilitation by providing real-time, quantitative visual feedback to both the patient and the therapist. Specifically, the project is planning to 1) develop a low-cost instrumentation and visualization platform centered around the Nintendo Wii Balance Board, 2) use this platform to quantify the effects of visual feedback on both patients and therapists during balance retraining, and 3) develop the ability to predict patient functional outcomes in real time from data collected during typical rehabilitation activities. The effort includes the development of a clinically appropriate control interface and quantification of the performance of a system consisting of multiple Wii Balance Boards, multiple web cams, and other devices to provide real-time visual feedback based on fused data from all of these sources.

Balance recovery is assessed between matched groups who receive therapy with and without feedback. Comparisons of self-awareness in the same groups is used to examine the role of feedback in developing a patient?s metacognitive knowledge. Therapists? interaction styles and treatment plans are compared between the groups to identify the effects of the feedback on their work. Finally, the investigators plan to identify which instrumented activities provide data that best predict a patient?s score on established functional assessment tools. Ultimately, this project seeks to enhance quality of life post-stroke by helping to optimize therapy during the acute phase, which is the most critical stage of recovery. The results will also be directly applicable to balance rehabilitation in chronic stroke and other neurotrauma and more broadly applicable to amputees and sports medicine patients. Most critically, the low cost of the instrumentation platform is designed to remove financial adoption barriers, allowing virtually any rehabilitation facility to leverage the results of the research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project developed an inexpensive system to enable physical therapists to provide visual feedback to patients during balance rehabilitation activities. The project also used this system to investigate how that visual feedback could 1) be optimized to help improve rehabilitation outcomes and 2) alter the types of interactions between therapists and their patients during a balance rehabilitation session.

 

The WeHab system consists of custom software that runs on a typical notebook or desktop computer and enables a physical therapist to lead a patient through standard balance therapy activities with visual feedback provided on the computer screen. A Nintendo Wii Balance Board connects to the computer via Bluetooth to provide the center of pressure measurement on which the visual feedback is based. A Nintendo Wiimote also connects via Bluetooth to enable the therapist to remotely control the software so that he/she can remain next to the patient throughout the therapy session. The WeHab software is available free for download at http://wehab.nd.edu. Because the other required components are widely available off-the-shelf gaming peripherals (in addition to a computer), the entire system can be assembled at a cost low enough to make visual feedback for balance therapy accessible to most rehabilitation clinics and even in some individuals' homes. 

 

Experiments using the WeHab system demonstrated that both young and older healthy subjects exhibited superior balance performance when given visual feedback directly showing the position of their center of pressure under their feet as compared to feedback showing the relative percentage of their weight supported by each foot. With the favored type of feedback, subjects exhibited less sway in static balance and faster weight shifts to either side. Subjects undergoing balance therapy in the clinic exhibited some characteristics comparable to their age-matched healthy counterparts (and other characteristics indicative of balance deficits), suggesting that the same type of feedback may be optimal for rehabilitation. Additional experiments with young, healthy subjects showed that filtering the feedback, which adds time delay, encourages faster, more vigorous shifts. Similar experiments showed that altering the feedback to augment deviations of the subject's center of pressure motion from a standard trajectory led to faster learning of a lateral weight shifting task. In summary, these experiments demonstrate 1) how the type of feedback can be selected to make a balance task more or less difficult during rehabilitation and 2) how the actual feedback can be manipulated to encourage a subject to improve his/her balance performance more quickly. In combination with the easy access to visual feedback provided by the WeHab system, these findings have the potential to help physical therapists improve rehabilitation outcomes for their balance patients. 

 

Other analysis of the data led to the development of a relatively simple model of balance control that can accurately match both the duration of a lateral weight shift and the initial motion of the center-of-pressure in the opposite direction of the weight shift, which characterizes the forcefulness of the shift. Text analysis of transcripts from therapy sessions both with and without visual feedback has shown that the presence of feedback appears to alter the interaction between the patient and the therapist.

 

The WeHab system has also proven to be a useful outreach tool in demonstrating to K-12 students how computer science and engineering can be applied to directly improve the quality of life for individuals who have had a stroke.
